name: Jorge Martinez
bio: Chef Jorge Martinez is a classically trained chef who specializes in traditional Mexican cuisine. With a focus on using fresh, locally-sourced ingredients and time-honored techniques, Chef Martinez's dishes are both authentic and delicious.

recipes.cookingMethod: 1. Boil tomatillos, onion, garlic, and jalapeño until soft. 2. Blend with cilantro. 3. Cook shredded chicken. 4. Dip tortillas in sauce, fill with chicken, and roll up. 5. Place in a baking dish, top with remaining sauce and cheese. 6. Bake until cheese is melted and bubbly.

1. Roast and peel poblano peppers. 2. Cook ground beef, onion, and garlic. 3. Add raisins, almonds, and tomatoes. 4. Stuff peppers with filling. 5. Dip in egg batter and fry until golden brown. 6. Serve with tomato sauce.

1. Soak corn husks in water. 2. Cook pork, tomatoes, onion, garlic, and chili powder. 3. Mix masa harina with broth. 4. Spread masa on husks, add meat filling, and fold. 5. Steam for about an hour. 6. Serve with salsa.

name: Alejandro Torres
bio: Chef Alejandro Torres is a talented chef who blends traditional Mexican flavors with modern culinary techniques to create dishes that are both familiar and unique. With a focus on using fresh, seasonal ingredients, Chef Torres's cuisine is both flavorful and sustainable.

recipes.cookingMethod: 1. Toast and soak chili peppers. 2. Cook chicken. 3. Blend chili peppers, tomatoes, onion, garlic, cinnamon, almonds, and raisins. 4. Fry tortillas. 5. Dip tortillas and chicken in sauce, and serve together.

1. Roast and peel poblano peppers. 2. Cook ground pork, onion, garlic, and cinnamon. 3. Add chopped apples, pears, and peach, as well as walnuts, almonds, and raisins. 4. Stuff peppers with filling. 5. Top with a walnut cream sauce and pomegranate seeds.
1. Marinate pork shoulder in achiote paste, pineapple, onion, garlic, cumin, and oregano. 2. Grill or roast until cooked through. 3. Serve on tortillas with chopped onion, cilantro, and pineapple.

name: Carlos Martinez
bio: Chef Carlos Martinez is a master of Mexican street food, with a particular focus on tacos. His signature dishes are simple yet delicious, made with fresh ingredients and bold flavors that capture the essence of Mexican cuisine.

recipes.cookingMethod: 1. Marinate skirt steak in lime juice, orange juice, garlic, cumin, coriander, and chili powder. 2. Grill or pan-fry until cooked to desired doneness. 3. Slice and serve on tortillas with your favorite toppings.

1. Fry tortilla strips until crispy. 2. Cook tomatoes, onion, garlic, and jalapeño in chicken broth. 3. Blend until smooth. 4. Add tortilla strips and cook until soft. 5. Serve with chopped avocado, cheese, and cilantro.
1. Roast and peel poblano peppers. 2. Stuff with queso fresco. 3. Dredge in flour and coat in beaten eggs. 4. Fry in oil until golden brown. 5. Serve with your favorite salsa.

name: Carlos Ramirez
bio: Carlos Ramirez is originally from Puebla, Mexico and learned to cook from his mother. He honed his skills working in restaurants throughout Mexico and the United States. His specialty is creating new dishes that blend traditional Mexican ingredients with international flavors.

recipes.cookingMethod: 1. Cook pork shoulder until tender. 2. Soak and blend dried chilies with onion, garlic, oregano, and cumin. 3. Add blended mixture to pork and hominy. 4. Serve with sliced radish, lime, and tostadas.

1. Cook chicken and shred. 2. Cook tomatillos, onion, and garlic until soft. 3. Blend until smooth. 4. Mix in sour cream. 5. Dip tortillas in sauce and fill with chicken. 6. Top with cheese and bake until melted. 7. Serve with chopped cilantro.
1. Soak corn husks in water. 2. Mix masa with chicken broth. 3. Spread masa onto corn husks. 4. Add chicken and tomatillo salsa. 5. Wrap and steam for 1 hour. 6. Serve with your favorite toppings.

name: Antonio Gonzalez
bio: Chef Antonio Gonzalez is a master of Mexican street food, with a particular focus on tacos. His signature dishes are simple yet delicious, made with fresh ingredients and bold flavors that capture the essence of Mexican cuisine.

recipes.cookingMethod: 1. Toast and soak dried chilies. 2. Blend chilies with onion,garlic, cumin, and oregano. 3. Brown beef chuck in a pot. 4. Add blended mixture, bay leaves, and water. 5. Simmer until beef is tender. 6. Serve with rice and beans.

1. Marinate pork shoulder with achiote paste, pineapple, onion, garlic, and guajillo chilies. 2. Roast in the oven until tender. 3. Serve on corn tortillas with diced pineapple, chopped cilantro, and lime wedges.

1. Toast vermicelli until golden brown. 2. Blend tomatoes, onion, and garlic. 3. Cook blended mixture in a pot. 4. Add chicken broth and vermicelli. 5. Simmer until vermicelli is tender. 6. Serve with diced avocado, chopped cilantro, and lime wedges.

name: Juan Hernandez
bio: Juan Hernandez grew up in Mexico City and learned to cook from his grandmother. He went on to study at the Culinary Institute of Mexico and has since worked in top restaurants in Mexico and the United States. His specialty is traditional Mexican cuisine with a modern twist.

recipes.cookingMethod: 1. Roast and peel poblano peppers. 2. Sauté shrimp, tomatoes, onion, and garlic. 3. Stuff mixture into peppers with queso fresco. 4. Dredge in cornstarch and coat in beaten eggs. 5. Fry in oil until golden brown. 6. Serve with rice and beans.

1. Cook chicken thighs and shred. 2. Blend tomatoes, onion, garlic, and chipotle chilies. 3. Cook blended mixture with shredded chicken. 4. Serve on tostadas with sliced avocado, shredded lettuce, and crumbled queso fresco.
1. Cook rice in milk. 2. Add sugar, cinnamon, raisins, and vanilla extract. 3. Simmer until thick and creamy. 4. Serve warm or chilled.
